comments.commentBody: No you said right, :"Defective."

Washington hard liners who want conflict with Russia are pushing Putin having interfered in the U.S. election. This serves two purposes: conflict with Russia and distracting attention from how swing state voting was manipulated by Republicans to give Trump victory.

This reporting by Greg Palast has been all but drowned out by exaggerating Russia's involvement in the election:

https://www.democracynow.org/2016/12/13/greg_palast_by_rejecting_recount_is
Just read the link.  If true -- and seems well-documented -- why isn't this being investigated more?   Where are the NY Times and others on this?

We just returned from a short trip 2,000 miles from our shores, the island of Curacao less than 40 miles from Venezuela. I was very much looking forward to getting out of here for a time to relieve the stress brought on by the fact that millions preferred a spectacularly unqualified man to someone who had studied, prepared and gathered experience to handle one of the most difficult jobs in the world, the presidency. Away, the brain refused to turn off.

I fear for the future of our nation and I will celebrate not one moment when many of the millions who voted for Trump see what a radical mistake they made. The consequences will be too dire for joyful noise.

About the only hope is the thought that Trumpism might lead to some sort of realignment and a coming to the senses whereby rancid, unending partisanship is pushed to the side. I have unbounded hope in the American public to find the right way, even if right now depression is the natural path.

America, by the way, is not in decay. The roads you wrote about, with exceptions, are the envy of the world, well planned, built and maintained. America also remains the creative energy source of the world, energy built on the lack of a firm class structure and the ability of quick minds and flowing capital to rearrange the old and imagine the new. Relax.

We have deep problems and Trumpism threatens to make them much worse. Still, adversity is well known for the advantages it offers the alert and the eager, American qualities.
comments.userLocation: Beyond the Beltway state of mind

comments.commentBody:
" America, by the way, is not in decay. The roads you wrote about, with exceptions, are the envy of the world, well planned, built and maintained. "

It's unarguable that US roads were well-planned and well-engineered. One only has to try to drive out of Sydney along the only realistic route out of the city to the west - Parramatta Road - to see what lack of planning and lack of good engineering can result in. The U.S. did a stellar job in infrastructure development but that was all decades ago. Well-maintained?????? Who are you kidding? Not for 35+ years! Most of the bridges on the Interstate system are more than 20 years' overdue for replacement. While the basic engineering behind the U.S. highways system remains despite this lack of maintenance, the actual surface of our highways is appalling - riddled with potholes and uneven pavement that's more like that of the road surfaces in 3rd world countries than that of a major world power.

Australia's inter-city rail system is on a par with that in the U.S., perhaps providing a reason for that aspect of national infrastructure going unmentioned here - both lag 50 years behind the rail systems of Europe, China, and Japan.

I wondered about the roads bit, myself. Are US roads worse than Australian roads? Remember we have a LOT more people -- 12 times as many - in roughly the same space (continental US is close to the size of Australia!) -- and in most of the US, we have a rough winter climate 7 months of the year. This is devastating to any roads and bridges.

Australia has a climate similar to that of Southern California -- mild all year, no winters. Is it really fair to compare road maintenance in such a gentle climate to (say) Milwaukee or Cleveland or Boston?

For what it is worth, in my Midwest area they are working on roads at least 9 months of the year. Our "orange barrels" are almost a joke. We just had all the major bridges downtown completely rebuilt from scratch at a cost of hundreds of millions of dollars. So I think this allegation is grossly unfair.

Have you been to China or talked to any Americans who work or have worked there?  You would be surprised how many have chosen to move there permanently and they aren't Communists, but business people who went there for the opportunities and excellent education system for their children.

It's been a long, gradual slide and many Americans would agree that Australia and other democracies have outpaced us in terms of gains for the average citizen and a prevailing sense of tolerance and decency.   I dare say that, if it were not for the pull of family and familiarity, plenty of us would consider leaving...   I always planned to visit Australia-   how welcoming are you guys to retiring ex-pats from America?   ; )

@Pat B.: every election cycle where Democrats lose....they swear they will move to Australia, Europe, Canada. There are some HILARIOUS follow-up articles showing that virtually nobody ever does so.

Just ask Amy Schumer and Lena Dunham who SWORE to the media that they were "leaving!" if Trump won. Of course, they said this when they believed Hillary was going to win a landslide victory. After the election, they got curiously silent and when pressed....started angrily saying "you can't make me leave my own nation!" Huh. Hypocrites!

BTW: Neither Australia nor New Zealand nor Canada is "welcoming" to older retirees or immigrants over 45 (!!!) and they demand not just a job, college and desirable skills but money in the bank to prove you can afford to settle there. Canada has a "points" system so harsh, that most Americans would be rejected right off the bat.

Their STRICT immigration laws, strictly enforced, is why they are "doing better" than the US -- they don't have to support a huge underclass of poor, unskilled illegal aliens with anchor babies. (Australia and New Zealand have voted and BANNED birthright citizenship for this very reason.)

Ridiculous. You fail to take note of the many recent American innovations that have transformed global communications, global science, global medicine. Your disparagement of legitimate human rights issues reveals the stunning lack of empathy and understanding that characterizes today's Trump voters. I'm sure you're aware that the blue states which support the economically weak red states are also the engines of the economic growth you imagine will follow the Trump election. Remember this: imagination and innovation flourish when freedom is flourishing. The republican agenda- misogynist, undemocratic, authoritarian- is in no way compatible with "greatness".
Watch those vaunted "opportunities" slowly disappear, if they ever actually existed.
Roger Cohen picks up this theme - America is an ideal. Stripped of the moral strengths, we who believe in freedom, human rights, a better humanity, are worse off.  Canadians feel the same....

Well by all means, let's give everything else up so that we can have guns.  Maybe we can get rid of all the other amendments to the Constitution, and just rename the 2nd amendment, the constitution.  It would certainly simplify things for some folks.

The problem is that there is no longer any time for right to prevail over wrong.  It's already arguably too late to prevent the consequences of global warming, and spending the next 8 years making things worse will certainly put the kabosh on that effort.  So no, the rest of the world cannot depend on the United States.
Hunh.  did that moon landing really happen?

America was exhausted by 2 wars and was severely damaged economically. It had to step back. It did so correctly with Obama. Conveniently, now as memory fades, what was smart repositioning is seen as retreat now. It was not close to that, and no sane person believes America will not strike back violently hard if attacked.

I simply would not bet against America. It's a tad premature to write its dirge, Trump notwithstanding. Are you that frail a citizen that you have no heart left to believe in your country?

Funny... when I visited Australia 15 years ago, I greatly enjoyed the feeling of being utterly isolated from America and the much more global perspective of the media.  However, I think both us Americans and many others are taking this election too seriously.  Sure, it's a shock and unfortunate and will be worse the Bush presidency, but remember that 3 million MORE Americans voted for Hillary.  The over-whelming majority of the youth vote, voted for either Hillary or Bernie.  The darker the night, the nearer the morning.  This is probably our darkest moment.  I'm confident the under 30 vote (today) will wake up in 4 years and sweep Michelle Obama or someone like her back into office.  What's more of an issue is the potential for an American civil war brought about by the utterly recalcitrant and irrational conservatives and republicans who put the party's name ahead of all else.

I hope you're correct, but I worry that we will still have the right to vote four years from now. No hyperbole, it's already begun. Take a look at what happened today in North Carolina. Read about the effects of gerrymandering, particularly in states such as Texas. Keep in mind that Conservatives will have a majority on the Supreme Court for the next 20 to 30 years. I'm not as optimistic. About the US continuing as a democratic republic.

Good lord, did you take away NOTHING from this election about how Americans dislike "dynasties" and resent the idea of an ex President's wife being elected based on nothing but the fame of her last name?

Any talk of the Electors and Electoral College should always include the reason for this strange way of choosing a President.  It's here because, and only because, of slavery.  The Southern slave states were fearful of losing power to the more populous North non-slave states.  They devised this method - certainly not democratic - to keep power.  Slavery is the original sin of this country and in helping to elect Donald Trump to the highest office, it continues to cause havoc.
Mr. Trump has no tax dollars in the game.

In that nation that led the world against tyranny in two world wars, we believed in democratic institutions, separation of powers, transparency and avoiding conflicts of interest, civility, and working with the opposition party when possible.  We did not believe in trashing government agencies, threatening to jail political opponents, shutting out the free press, bullying and publicly threatening anyone and everyone who might disagree, and maximizing politicians own financial gain.   If you don't believe this, you need to read about the Roosevelt, Truman, and Eisenhower adminstrations.

"We are mourning the slow, painful death of America being caused by the never ending wounds inflicted by Trump's onslaught of destructive, unqualified appointments to our governments departments and agencies everyday."

LorenRosalin, one bit of information I would like to add to your eloquent response. The Republican Party is responsible for Trump, and it was helped by a very large section of an uneducated, provincial public.
Perhaps; for the author but to me its been a lifting of 8 years of gloom and excessive government do gooding.

I hear you.  I just can't wait until 21,000,000 Americans lose their health insurance with the repeal of Obamacare.  Bach to the good old days, when almost 45,000 Americans were dying preventable deaths every year because of lack of coverage and the ongoing care that coverage makes possible.
I far prefer the do-gooding of the outgoing administration to the promise of do-bading of the incoming one.
Heaven forbid we do good. We are set to do a whole lot of bad, and I guess that pleases you, 1515732.

One big problem in the US is it's a large continental country. People in the interior are so far removed from and insulated from the rest of the world that for many of them their thinking becomes ingrown and insular. It's the outcome you would expect from the societal equivalent of incest: bad stuff gets worse. Continuing migration from the interior to the coastal cities, as well as immigration to the same, will eventually take care of this problem. But for now, we are still stuck with it.

What an incredibly condescending attitude. Some of the biggest hicks I've known came from New York City. Go ahead and keep telling yourself that, but in actuality what you had in Obama was a cult of personality -- and that didn't carry over to Hillary Clinton.

While you ponder how flyover country could still be stubborn as to not totally accept the progressive agenda, even as those residents are called stupid and ignorant for not doing so (The floggings will continue until morale improves!), you might also ponder why the Democrats have steadily lost influence at the federal and state level over the last eight years. Since 2009 Republicans have majorities in both houses of Congress, 35 of 50 governorships, and approximately 65% of State-level seats. That's a collapse of epic proportions, and should suggest a look in the mirror for the cause, rather than blame those poor benighted fools living in the heartland.

I have canceled my NYT subscription, exhausted by its agenda, then its hyperbolic tone post-election, and now by its readers' anxiety and hyperbole. What frail citizens you are, to tremble in fear at Trump, as if helpless. Stop already with the anxiety and get to work fighting.
Horrors? Seriously? Despite the ups and downs we've done pretty well for 200+ years, no? Cut it out.
Donald Trump and "honest" in the same sentence is a non -sequiter, just check with any fact checking organization.

Well, lets be clear. The majority of the jobs did go to cheap labor.

And a LOT of people benefited from it --but not them.

They only ask their government to represent their best interests.

"Most liberals live in highly segregated communities where only liberals are allowed" is a statement devoid of fact. Ditto for "the liberal establishment is about as tolerant and diversified as a KKK rally." I think your prejudices are showing.

Can you picture Donald Trump in a barn? At any time in his life? He might mess-up the Brioni.

Putin didn’t “try to interfere with our election”. Putin succeeded at destroying Debbie Wasserman Schultz and making a laughingstock of John Podesta. He deserves a Nobel for SOMETHING on both counts. Maybe for “Contributions to Global Decorum”? Pity he didn’t set his sights on Harry Reid.

But the bromance isn’t so hard to figure out. Both these guys have senses of humor. For Trump, it’s a little vengeful, like leading on Mitt Romney, getting him to eat about three tons of crow, then dropping him like High School French after finding out only guys signed up. For Putin, it’s a little different. “So, Saddam, you drop enemies into bone-crushers feet first? You’re such a kidder.” I double-dare Trump, when he meets Putin for the first time pres-to-pres, to affect a Russian accent and say: “You are former KGB, so you would know. Where ARE moose and squirrel?”

But Gail can’t assert with knowledge that Putin didn’t call Trump a “genius” when they were in adjoining stables being rubbed-down and fed double-whoppers with cheese by the last two Miss Universes.

BOTH Putin AND Trump are men who have used other men like barnyard animals for their own purposes. I wouldn’t set much stock in the “bromance” when they’re dickering over their countries’ interests.

Richard, what's your fixation with "sense of humor"?   It looks like you are trying to rationalize the behavior of two dangerous men neither of whom is in the least amusing.  If they are funny at all, it is in the sense of sinister characters in a Batman movie.

At this point, I see the concept of Trump and Putin "dickering over their countries' interests" as amounting to one in which the former's responses to everything the latter proposes can be summarized by the words "Da, Tovarisch."  Which is likely as much Russian as The Donald will ever need to learn. I'm tempted to say that were I Syrian or Ukrainian I'd be cursing the day these two men ever made each other's acquaintance (whether in a stable or at a demagogue convention).  Then again, I can feel the anger and the dismay just being right here at home.

If those are examples of Trump and Putin's "humor," they have something else in common: neither is funny.

Putin grabbed all sorts of information and released it selectively. By all accounts, he's got plenty left in his arsenal. Let's see what comes out over the next four years, aimed at Trump, as they engage in "dickering." And let's imagine how that might affect US interests.
